Award.AwardTitle: Algebraic and Geometric Methods in Data Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The diversity of biological forms and the nature of their variation lend themselves to geometric data analysis by topological methods. These methods quantify shape by recording the values of parameters (such as height, thickness, time, distance, temperature, or curvature) across which the topology of the geometric object changes: holes emerge or collapse; connected components join or diverge; cavities form or fill. Current geometric methods of this sort can handle one varying parameter, but data often call for more than one. This project develops an algebraic framework to encode and compute in the context of this multiparameter topological data analysis. The proposed methodology is general, applicable to datasets from any scientific inquiry, but it is being developed here in service to a fundamental question in evolutionary biology: what mechanism drives the generation of topological variants in sufficient quantity for selection to act? The model organism for this investigation is the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, specifically the pattern of veins in its wings.

This project develops mathematical foundations for multiparameter persistent homology. This investigation is in service to a specific question in evolutionary biology, using fruit fly wings as the model system, but the proposed methodology is general, applying homological algebra, real algebraic geometry, combinatorics, and computational techniques to encode, control, and provide insight theoretically as well as for applied and algorithmic purposes. The parameters are allowed to vary continuously on stratified spaces, instead of the usual discrete setup with one parameter on a simplicial complex. As such, the project transforms the way we think about commutative algebra in two independent ways simultaneously: by considering real vectors or an arbitrary poset instead of integer vectors for multigradings, and by splicing together the augmentation maps of free and injective resolutions to get "fringe presentations" of modules. The combination of techniques from free resolutions and injective resolutions also transforms how we think about topology and geometry, since it renders the new conception of multiparameter persistent homology transparent topologically -- features are described in terms of birth and death (generators and cogenerators) rather than by birth and relations between births (generators and relations) -- while greatly expanding the potential for effective computation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Statistical methods for geometric data are not currently set up to
handle drastic, discontinuous shape changes, akin to addition of a
sixth finger to a five-fingered hand as opposed to, say, lengthening
the hand as a whole.  These shape changes occur in evolution, but
often the pressures to maintain the original shape are so strong that
errant shapes occur only rarely in each generation.  But if shape
variation of this sort is so rare, how can selection act to encourage
populations exhibiting the rare variant to flourish?  That is, given a
discrete morphological feature that rarely varies in wild populations,
how can evolutionary forces generate qualitatively new features with
enough frequency for selection to act?  The grant was aimed, in the
long term, at answering this biological question, starting from a
dataset of photographic images of fruit fly wings that exhibit this
strong shape maintenance with rare shape variation.

Answering the biological question requires statistical methods that
can handle families of shapes whose topology -- that is, their overall
structure -- varies.  Persistent homology is one possible such method,
a multiscale analysis that takes into account what data look like as
the view zooms in and out.  However, one parameter to record the zoom
factor is not sensitive enough to handle topological variation in the
fly wing data.  On the other hand, while multiple parameters allow
enough freedom, in principle, to capture the topological variation,
working with multiparameter persistent homology requires new
mathematics, both for theory and for algorithms.

What kind of new mathematics is required?  Ordinary algebra deals with
polynomials, where variables are multiplied a whole number of times,
so the exponents are integers.  In contrast, because of the way
multiparameter persistent homology is encoded algebraically, the
continuous quantities common in data analysis yield exponents that are
real numbers instead of integers.

The main thrust of this project laid foundations for the algebra of
polynomials with real exponents instead of integer exponents.  As a
result, multiscale statistical methods based on persistent homology
with more than one real parameter now have mathematically precise and
-- crucially -- finite data structures suitable for algorithmic
implementation.  This mathematics has brought the data analysis closer
to being able to answer the motivating fundamental question in
evolutionary biology.

Other aspects of the project improve efficiency of symbolic
computational techniques with systems of polynomial equations or
provide startling symbolic methods to carry out computational tasks
not previously deemed possible.  These developments are fueled by
advances in deep areas of geometry using discrete structures that
govern the newly laid algebraic foundations, or by landmark advances
in algebra.  Among these are the first steps in the entirely uncharted
realm of polynomials with real exponents and the solution of a
central, widely known, half-century old problem at the interface of
algebra and discrete mathematics.

The rich mix of subject areas, including aspects of mathematics,
statistics, computation, and biology naturally lends itself to
multidisciplinary collaboration and mentoring opportunities.  Broadly
under the auspices of the grant, the PI mentored four undergraduates,
four graduate students, and one postdoc to fruitful next steps in
their development.  In the meantime, three undergraduates and two
graduate students joined the project on a continuing basis, with two
or three postdoctoral advisees to join shortly.  The research
undertaken and completed by these advisees spans the range of subject
areas and beyond, contributing to pairs of topics such as computation
and geometry or statistics and biology.

All of the completed research, by the PI as well as the PI's advisees,
was formally written and appropriately made public.  The content was
also conveyed directly by lectures and minicourses to audiences
ranging from high-school students and undergraduates to seasoned
researchers specializing in mathematics, statistics, and biology, as
well as occasionally philosophy and history of evolutionary theory.
Further opportunities for dissemination were created by the PI and
collaborators by workshop organization.

Outreach to the wider community, beyond research and mentoring,
included activities such as interfacing with middle-grades educators
in the challenging Durham Public Schools district and consulting with
local major network television meteorologists to help with display of
data uncertainty for primetime on-air public consumption.
